segment.source: 3-D perspective effects for XAML UI
segment.target: 3-D perspective effects for XAML UI

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: You can apply 3-D effects to content in your Windows Runtime apps using perspective transforms.
segment.target: You can apply 3-D effects to content in your Windows Runtime apps using perspective transforms.

segment.source: For example, you can create the illusion that an object is rotated toward or away from you, as shown here.
segment.target: For example, you can create the illusion that an object is rotated toward or away from you, as shown here.

segment.source: Another common usage for perspective transforms is to arrange objects in relation to one another to create a 3-D effect, as here.
segment.target: Another common usage for perspective transforms is to arrange objects in relation to one another to create a 3-D effect, as here.

source.pc: Stacking objects to create a 3-D effect

target.pc: Stacking objects to create a 3-D effect

segment.source: Besides creating static 3-D effects, you can animate the perspective transform properties to create moving 3-D effects.
segment.target: Besides creating static 3-D effects, you can animate the perspective transform properties to create moving 3-D effects.

segment.source:
Run this sample
to see an example of this.
segment.target:
Run this sample
to see an example of this.

segment.source: You just saw perspective transforms applied to images, but you can apply these effects to any **UIElement**, including controls.
segment.target: You just saw perspective transforms applied to images, but you can apply these effects to any **UIElement**, including controls.

segment.source: For example, you can apply a 3-D effect to an entire container of controls like this:
segment.target: For example, you can apply a 3-D effect to an entire container of controls like this:

source.pc: 3-D effect applied to a container of elements

target.pc: 3-D effect applied to a container of elements

segment.source: Here is the XAML code used to create this sample:
segment.target: Here is the XAML code used to create this sample:

segment.source: Here we focus on the properties of **PlaneProjection** which is used to rotate and move objects in 3-D space.
segment.target: Here we focus on the properties of **PlaneProjection** which is used to rotate and move objects in 3-D space.

segment.source: The next sample allows you to experiment with these properties and see their effect on an object.
segment.target: The next sample allows you to experiment with these properties and see their effect on an object.

segment.source: PlaneProjection class
segment.target: PlaneProjection class

segment.source: You can apply 3D effects can to any **UIElement**, by setting the UIElement's **Projection** property using a **PlaneProjection**.
segment.target: You can apply 3D effects can to any **UIElement**, by setting the UIElement's **Projection** property using a **PlaneProjection**.

segment.source: The PlaneProjection defines how the transform is rendered in space.
segment.target: The PlaneProjection defines how the transform is rendered in space.

segment.source: The next example shows a simple case.
segment.target: The next example shows a simple case.

segment.source: This figure shows what the image renders as.
segment.target: This figure shows what the image renders as.

segment.source: The x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis are shown as red lines.
segment.target: The x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis are shown as red lines.

segment.source: The image is rotated backward 35 degrees around the x-axis using the **RotationX** property.
segment.target: The image is rotated backward 35 degrees around the x-axis using the **RotationX** property.

segment.source: The **RotationY** property rotates around the y-axis of the center of rotation.
segment.target: The **RotationY** property rotates around the y-axis of the center of rotation.

segment.source: The **RotationZ** property rotates around the z-axis of the center of rotation (a line that is perpendicular to the plane of the object).
segment.target: The **RotationZ** property rotates around the z-axis of the center of rotation (a line that is perpendicular to the plane of the object).

segment.source: The rotation properties can specify a positive or negative value to rotate in either direction.
segment.target: The rotation properties can specify a positive or negative value to rotate in either direction.

segment.source: The absolute number can be greater than 360, which rotates the object more than one full rotation.
segment.target: The absolute number can be greater than 360, which rotates the object more than one full rotation.

segment.source:
Run this sample
to experiment with different values for the **RotationX**, **RotationY**, and **RotationZ** properties to see the effect.
segment.target:
Run this sample
to experiment with different values for the **RotationX**, **RotationY**, and **RotationZ** properties to see the effect.

segment.source: You can move the center of rotation by using the **CenterOfRotationX**, **CenterOfRotationY**, and **CenterOfRotationZ** properties.
segment.target: You can move the center of rotation by using the **CenterOfRotationX**, **CenterOfRotationY**, and **CenterOfRotationZ** properties.

segment.source: By default, the axes of rotation run directly through the center of the object, causing the object to rotate around its center.
segment.target: By default, the axes of rotation run directly through the center of the object, causing the object to rotate around its center.

segment.source: But if you move the center of rotation to the outer edge of the object, it will rotate around that edge.
segment.target: But if you move the center of rotation to the outer edge of the object, it will rotate around that edge.

segment.source: The default values for CenterOfRotationX and CenterOfRotationY are 0.5, and the default value for CenterOfRotationZ is 0.
segment.target: The default values for CenterOfRotationX and CenterOfRotationY are 0.5, and the default value for CenterOfRotationZ is 0.

segment.source: For CenterOfRotationX and CenterOfRotationY, values between 0 and 1 set the pivot point at some location within the object.
segment.target: For CenterOfRotationX and CenterOfRotationY, values between 0 and 1 set the pivot point at some location within the object.

segment.source: A value of 0 denotes one object edge and 1 denotes the opposite edge.
segment.target: A value of 0 denotes one object edge and 1 denotes the opposite edge.

segment.source: Values outside of this range are allowed and will move the center of rotation accordingly.
segment.target: Values outside of this range are allowed and will move the center of rotation accordingly.

segment.source: Because the z-axis of the center of rotation is drawn through the plane of the object, you can move the center of rotation behind the object using a negative number and in front of the object (toward you) using a positive number.
segment.target: Because the z-axis of the center of rotation is drawn through the plane of the object, you can move the center of rotation behind the object using a negative number and in front of the object (toward you) using a positive number.

segment.source:
**CenterOfRotationX**
moves the center of rotation along the x-axis parallel to the object while **CenterOfRotationY** moves the center or rotation along the y-axis of the object.
segment.target:
**CenterOfRotationX**
moves the center of rotation along the x-axis parallel to the object while **CenterOfRotationY** moves the center or rotation along the y-axis of the object.

segment.source: The next illustrations demonstrate using different values for CenterOfRotationY.
segment.target: The next illustrations demonstrate using different values for CenterOfRotationY.

segment.source: Notice how the image rotates around the center when the **CenterOfRotationY** property is set to the default value of 0.5 and rotates near the upper edge when set to 0.1.
segment.target: Notice how the image rotates around the center when the **CenterOfRotationY** property is set to the default value of 0.5 and rotates near the upper edge when set to 0.1.

segment.source: You see similar behavior when changing the **CenterOfRotationX** property to move where the **RotationY** property rotates the object.
segment.target: You see similar behavior when changing the **CenterOfRotationX** property to move where the **RotationY** property rotates the object.

segment.source: Use the **CenterOfRotationZ** to place the center of rotation above or below the plane of the object.
segment.target: Use the **CenterOfRotationZ** to place the center of rotation above or below the plane of the object.

segment.source: This way, you can rotate the object around the point analogous to a planet orbiting around a star.
segment.target: This way, you can rotate the object around the point analogous to a planet orbiting around a star.

segment.source:
Run this slider sample
to experiment with rotating the object around different locations for the center of rotation.
segment.target:
Run this slider sample
to experiment with rotating the object around different locations for the center of rotation.

segment.source: Positioning an object
segment.target: Positioning an object

segment.source: So far, you learned how to rotate an object in space.
segment.target: So far, you learned how to rotate an object in space.

segment.source: You can position these rotated objects in space relative to one another by using these properties:
segment.target: You can position these rotated objects in space relative to one another by using these properties:

segment.source:
**LocalOffsetX**
moves an object along the x-axis of the plane of a rotated object.
segment.target:
**LocalOffsetX**
moves an object along the x-axis of the plane of a rotated object.

segment.source:
**LocalOffsetY**
moves an object along the y-axis of the plane of a rotated object.
segment.target:
**LocalOffsetY**
moves an object along the y-axis of the plane of a rotated object.

segment.source:
**LocalOffsetZ**
moves an object along the z-axis of the plane of a rotated object.
segment.target:
**LocalOffsetZ**
moves an object along the z-axis of the plane of a rotated object.

segment.source:
**GlobalOffsetX**
moves an object along the screen-aligned x-axis.
segment.target:
**GlobalOffsetX**
moves an object along the screen-aligned x-axis.

segment.source:
**GlobalOffsetY**
moves an object along the screen-aligned y-axis.
segment.target:
**GlobalOffsetY**
moves an object along the screen-aligned y-axis.

segment.source:
**GlobalOffsetZ**
moves an object along the screen-aligned z-axis.
segment.target:
**GlobalOffsetZ**
moves an object along the screen-aligned z-axis.

segment.source: The **LocalOffsetX**, **LocalOffsetY**, and **LocalOffsetZ** properties translate an object along the respective axis of the plane of the object after it has been rotated.
segment.target: The **LocalOffsetX**, **LocalOffsetY**, and **LocalOffsetZ** properties translate an object along the respective axis of the plane of the object after it has been rotated.

segment.source: Therefore, the rotation of the object determines the direction that the object is translated.
segment.target: Therefore, the rotation of the object determines the direction that the object is translated.

segment.source: To demonstrate this concept, the next sample animates LocalOffsetX from 0 to 400 and **RotationY** from 0 to 65 degrees.
segment.target: To demonstrate this concept, the next sample animates LocalOffsetX from 0 to 400 and **RotationY** from 0 to 65 degrees.

segment.source: Notice in the preceding sample that the object is moving along its own x-axis.
segment.target: Notice in the preceding sample that the object is moving along its own x-axis.

segment.source: At the very beginning of the animation, when the **RotationY** value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves along the screen in the x direction, but as the object rotates toward you, the object moves along the x-axis of the plane of the object toward you.
segment.target: At the very beginning of the animation, when the **RotationY** value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves along the screen in the x direction, but as the object rotates toward you, the object moves along the x-axis of the plane of the object toward you.

segment.source: On the other hand, if you animated the RotationY property to -65 degrees, the object would curve away from you.
segment.target: On the other hand, if you animated the RotationY property to -65 degrees, the object would curve away from you.

segment.source:
**LocalOffsetY**
works similarly to **LocalOffsetX**, except that it moves along the vertical axis, so changing **RotationX** affects the direction LocalOffsetY moves the object.
segment.target:
**LocalOffsetY**
works similarly to **LocalOffsetX**, except that it moves along the vertical axis, so changing **RotationX** affects the direction LocalOffsetY moves the object.

segment.source: In the next sample, LocalOffsetY is animated from 0 to 400 and RotationX from 0 to 65 degrees.
segment.target: In the next sample, LocalOffsetY is animated from 0 to 400 and RotationX from 0 to 65 degrees.

segment.source:
**LocalOffsetZ**
translates the object perpendicular to the plane of the object as though a vector was drawn directly through the center from behind the object out toward you.
segment.target:
**LocalOffsetZ**
translates the object perpendicular to the plane of the object as though a vector was drawn directly through the center from behind the object out toward you.

segment.source: To demonstrate how LocalOffsetZ works, the next sample animates LocalOffsetZ from 0 to 400 and **RotationX** from 0 to 65 degrees.
segment.target: To demonstrate how LocalOffsetZ works, the next sample animates LocalOffsetZ from 0 to 400 and **RotationX** from 0 to 65 degrees.

segment.source: At the beginning of the animation, when the **RotationX** value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves directly out toward you, but as the face of the object rotates down, the object moves down instead.
segment.target: At the beginning of the animation, when the **RotationX** value is near zero (parallel to the screen), the object moves directly out toward you, but as the face of the object rotates down, the object moves down instead.

segment.source: The **GlobalOffsetX**, **GlobalOffsetY**, and **GlobalOffsetZ** properties translate the object along axes relative to the screen.
segment.target: The **GlobalOffsetX**, **GlobalOffsetY**, and **GlobalOffsetZ** properties translate the object along axes relative to the screen.

segment.source: That is, unlike the local offset properties, the axis the object moves along is independent of any rotation applied to the object.
segment.target: That is, unlike the local offset properties, the axis the object moves along is independent of any rotation applied to the object.

segment.source: These properties are useful when you want to simply move the object along the x-, y-, or z-axis of the screen without worrying about the rotation applied to the object.
segment.target: These properties are useful when you want to simply move the object along the x-, y-, or z-axis of the screen without worrying about the rotation applied to the object.

segment.source: The next sample animates **GlobalOffsetX** from 0 to 400 and **RotationY** from 0 to 65 degrees.
segment.target: The next sample animates **GlobalOffsetX** from 0 to 400 and **RotationY** from 0 to 65 degrees.

segment.source: Notice in this sample that the object does not change course as it rotates.
segment.target: Notice in this sample that the object does not change course as it rotates.

segment.source: That is because the object is being moved along the x-axis of the screen without regard to its rotation.
segment.target: That is because the object is being moved along the x-axis of the screen without regard to its rotation.

segment.source: Positioning an object
segment.target: Positioning an object

segment.source: You can use the **Matrix3DProjection** and **Matrix3D** types for more complex semi-3D scenarios than are possible with the **PlaneProjection**.
segment.target: You can use the **Matrix3DProjection** and **Matrix3D** types for more complex semi-3D scenarios than are possible with the **PlaneProjection**.

segment.source: Matrix3DProjection provides you with a complete 3D transform matrix to apply to any **UIElement**, so that you can apply arbitrary model transformation matrices and perspective matrices to elements.
segment.target: Matrix3DProjection provides you with a complete 3D transform matrix to apply to any **UIElement**, so that you can apply arbitrary model transformation matrices and perspective matrices to elements.

segment.source: Keep in mind that these API are minimal and therefore if you use them, you will need to write the code that correctly creates the 3D transform matrices.
segment.target: Keep in mind that these API are minimal and therefore if you use them, you will need to write the code that correctly creates the 3D transform matrices.

segment.source: Because of this, it is easier to use PlaneProjection for simple 3D scenarios.
segment.target: Because of this, it is easier to use PlaneProjection for simple 3D scenarios.
